===Response=== [[File:Venezuela said NO to Hugo Chavez.jpg|thumb|270px|''[[El Nacional (Caracas)|El Nacional]]'' headline: "Venezuela said no".]] In conceding defeat, Ch√°vez insisted that he would "continue in the battle to build socialism".<ref name=MercoPraise/> Although two days later Chavez called "victoria de mierda" (shitty victory) to the results, further saying that "but already you are covering it (the victory) in shit".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2007/12/06/internacional/1196897757.html|title=Foreign media on the referendum|work=[[El Mundo(Caracas)|El Mundo]]|date=6 December 2007|accessdate=21 May 2008}}</ref> Ch√°vez conceded defeat by saying "for now, we couldn't" ''("por ahora no pudimos"''),<ref name=BloombergReject>Matthew Walter and Helen Murphy. [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aSpYEZW_eEhM&refer=home Venezuelans Reject Chavez's Plans for Constitution (Update1).] ''Bloomberg'', 3 December 2007. Accessed on 3 December 2007</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/internacional/Venezuela/dice/Constitucion/Chavez/elpepuint/20071203elpepuint_1/Tes|title=Venezuela dice 'no' a la Constituci√≥n de Ch√°vez|author=Peregil, F|date=3 December 2007|work=El Pa√≠s|accessdate=7 December 2007|language=es}}</ref> echoing the phrase he used after the failure of the [[1992 Venezuelan coup d'√©tat attempts|February 1992 Venezuelan coup d'√©tat attempt]].<ref name=ABCTension/><ref name=KCHail>{{cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/world/story/388018.html |title=Bush administration hails Chavez defeat |author=Bachelet, Pablo |work=McClatchy Newspapers |publisher=The Kansas City Star |date=3 December 2007 |accessdate=4 December 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206110705/http://www.kansascity.com/news/world/story/388018.html |archivedate=6 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> [[Manuel Rosales]], a [[Venezuelan presidential election, 2006|2006 Venezuelan presidential candidate]], said, "Tonight, Venezuela has won".<ref name=NYTNarrow/> [[Leopoldo L√≥pez]], a popular opposition mayor, said "Venezuela won today, democracy won today".<ref name=MercoPraise/>
[[Latin American]] media responses included special reports that highlighted Ch√°vez's first electoral setback in nine years and his ethical acceptance of defeat.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/12/03/en_refco_art_foreign-media-on-the_03A1242319.shtml|title=Foreign media on the referendum|work=[[El Universal (Caracas)|El Universal]]|date=3 December 2007|accessdate=4 December 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071217050653/http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/12/03/en_refco_art_foreign-media-on-the_03A1242319.shtml|archive-date=17 December 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to a [[Mercosur]] press release, the general Latin American response was praise for the "democratic maturity" evidenced by the Venezuelan people. Brazil's Foreign Affairs Minister, Celso Amorin, said "The president accepted the result in a very calm and elegant manner."<ref name=MercoPraise/> President Felipe Calder√≥n of Mexico said Ch√°vez had shown " ... enormous valor to admit such results".<ref name=MercoPraise/> Spain's Foreign Affairs minister, Miguel √Ångel Moratinos, said that "free expression of people's sovereignty has been accepted by all sides including those who had promoted the referendum".<ref name=MercoPraise/> [[N√©stor Kirchner]], [[Argentine President]] described Ch√°vez as a "great democrat".<ref name=MercoPraise/> A response characterized by Mercosur as "blunt" came from Cuban Foreign Affairs minister Felipe Perez Roque: "those who have organized plots to destabilize Venezuela, to abolish its democratically elected government and even attempt a coup against President Ch√°vez are active and we hope that they quit and let the Venezuelan people build their future in peace".<ref name=MercoPraise>{{cite press release|url=http://www.mercopress.com/vernoticia.do?id=12055&formato=HTML|date=4 December 2007|title=Praise for Venezuela but Chavez promises 'we will prevail'|publisher=MercoPress|accessdate=5 December 2007}}</ref>
The U.S. administration of President [[George W. Bush]] hailed the defeat as a victory for democracy. Bush said, "The Venezuelan people rejected one-man rule. They voted for democracy." A National Security Council spokesman said, "We congratulate the people of Venezuela on their vote and their continued desire to live in freedom and democracy".<ref name=KCHail /> A State Department Undersecretary said, "We felt that this referendum would make Ch√°vez president for life, and that‚Äôs not ever a welcome development. In a country that wants to be a democracy, the people spoke, and the people spoke for democracy and against unlimited power."<ref name=KCHail/>
The [[Organization of American States]] Secretary-General Jos√© Miguel Insulza called the results of the referendum an "exemplary development" on the part of the Venezuelan government and people, saying that democracy in the Americas "passed a difficult test and emerged stronger, showing clearly its consolidation."<ref name="ElUniOAS">{{cite news|url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/12/03/en_refco_art_insulza-congratulate_03A1242563.shtml|title=Insulza congratulates Venezuelan government and people|work=El Universal|date=3 December 2007|accessdate=5 December 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525130817/http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/12/03/en_refco_art_insulza-congratulate_03A1242563.shtml|archive-date=25 May 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Reporters without Borders]] expressed hope that the result of the vote would end the "media war" in Venezuela.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/12/03/en_refco_art_rsf-hopes-referendum_03A1241999.shtml|title=RSF hopes referendum to stop "media war" in Venezuela|work=[[El Universal (Caracas)|El Universal]]|date=3 December 2007|accessdate=4 December 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222203334/http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/12/03/en_refco_art_rsf-hopes-referendum_03A1241999.shtml|archive-date=22 December 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The day after the referendum, financial markets were buoyed by Ch√°vez's defeat; Venezuelan bonds rose and the stock index in Caracas surged 4% following a year-to-date 24% decline.<ref name=MarketEmerging>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/venezuelan-bonds-rally-after-chavez/story.aspx?guid=%7BD1EA2669-EA24-4725-9371-091CF53EA580%7D|title=Emerging Markets Report: Venezuelan bonds rally after Chavez referendum loss|author=Lesova, Polya Lesova|publisher=MarketWatch|date=3 December 2007|accessdate=5 December 2007}}</ref>
== Continued plans for reform == Ch√°vez said on 5 December that he intended to launch a second attempt to change the Constitution. According to ''[[El Universal (Caracas)|El Universal]]'' newspaper, he said:<ref name=EUSecond>{{cite news|url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/12/05/en_refco_art_chavez-announces-sec_05A1247117.shtml|title=Ch√°vez announces second offensive to reform the Constitution|work=El Universal|date=5 December 2007|accessdate=5 December 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525130923/http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/12/05/en_refco_art_chavez-announces-sec_05A1247117.shtml|archive-date=25 May 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>{{cquote|Watch out, US lovers, celebrate. You have no dignity anyhow. Where could you have it? I recommend you to administer your victory wisely, because we will launch a renewed offensive for the great constitutional reform. ... You have a second offensive left for the constitutional reform. I cannot say that we did not make it."}} Responding to George W. Bush's remarks, he said:<ref name=EUSecond/>{{quote|They say Ch√°vez was blown away. Yes, but I moved not even a millimeter. Yes, I was blown away, but I am weaker not even a millimeter. Be worried, empire; be worried, unpatriotic oligarchy. Strike as many times as you want. But, beware! Do not provoke!}} During a press conference with the military high command, he expressed on [[Venezolana de Televisi√≥n]] the possibility of bringing the proposal back in "the same form, transformed or simplified" in a future referendum and the creation of the bolivarian militias by modifying the laws regarding the armed forces. He also described the opposition's victory as "full of shit" and his defeat as "full of courage, valor and dignity".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://550.dreamhosters.com/yvke/noticia.php?1632|title=Presidente Ch√°vez: "Vendr√° una nueva ofensiva" para reformar la Carta Magna|publisher=YVKE Caracas|accessdate=5 December 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071213011118/http://550.dreamhosters.com/yvke/noticia.php?1632|archive-date=13 December 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globovision.com/news.php?nid=72946|title=Presidente Chavez desmiente haber sido presionado por alto mando militar y reitera que insistir√° en su proyecto|publisher=Globovisi√≥n|date=5 December 2007|accessdate=5 December 2007|language=es|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071207064614/http://www.globovision.com/news.php?nid=72946|archive-date=7 December 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
A month after the referendum was defeated, Ch√°vez named Ramon Carrizales to replace vice-president [[Jorge Rodr√≠guez (politician)|Jorge Rodr√≠guez]], who had been blamed by many Ch√°vez supporters for the failed referendum.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jack Daniel|first=Frank|title=Venezuela's Chavez reshuffles cabinet after defeat|date=3 January 2008|accessdate=22 January 2008|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSN0359066620080104?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0|work=[[Reuters]]}}</ref>

page.title: Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}}{{Infobox Treaty | name = Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer | long_name = | image = | image_width = | caption = | type = | date_drafted = | date_signed = 22 March 1985 | location_signed = [[Vienna]] | date_sealed = | date_effective = 22 September 1988 | condition_effective = ratification by 20 states | date_expiration = | signatories = 28<ref name = ratifications/> | ratifiers = 197<ref name = ratifications/> | depositor =[[Secretary-General of the United Nations]] | language = | languages =Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian and Spanish | website = | wikisource = }} The '''Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer''' is a [[International environmental agreement|multilateral environmental agreement]] signed in 1985 that provided frameworks for international reductions in the production of chlorofluorocarbons due to their contribution to the destruction of the [[ozone layer]] and resulting increase in the threat of skin cancer.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nolan|first=C.V.|last2=Amanatidis|first2=G.T.|date=1995|year=1995|title=European commission research on the fluxes and effects of environmental UVB radiation|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/1011-1344(95)07161-2|journal=Journal of Photochemistry and Photobiology B: Biology|volume=31|issue=1-2|pages=3‚Äì7|doi=10.1016/1011-1344(95)07161-2|issn=1011-1344|via=}}</ref> === Background === During the 1970's, research indicated that man-made [[Chlorofluorocarbon|chlorofluorocarbons]] (CFCs) reduce and convert [[ozone]] molecules in the atmosphere.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jachtenfuchs|first=M.|date=1990|title=The European Community and the Protection of the Ozone Layer|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1468-5965.1990.tb00367.x|journal=JCMS: Journal of Common Market Studies|language=en|volume=28|issue=3|pages=261‚Äì277|doi=10.1111/j.1468-5965.1990.tb00367.x|issn=0021-9886|via=}}</ref> CFCs are stable molecules composed of carbon, [[fluorine]], and [[chlorine]] that were used prominently in products such as refrigerators. The threats associated with reduced [[ozone]] pushed the issue to the forefront of global climate issues and gained promotion through organizations such as the [[World Meteorological Organization]] and the [[United Nations]]. The Vienna Convention was agreed upon at the [[Vienna Conference (1985)|Vienna Conference]] of 1985 and entered into force in 1988. The Vienna Convention provided the framework necessary to create regulatory measures in the form of the [[Montreal Protocol]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Slaper|first=H.|last2=Velders|first2=G. J. M.|last3=Daniel|first3=J. S.|last4=de Gruijl|first4=F. R.|last5=van der Leun|first5=J. C.|date=1996|title=Estimates of ozone depletion and skin cancer incidence to examine the Vienna Convention achievements|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/384256a0.pdf|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=384|issue=6606|pages=256‚Äì258|doi=10.1038/384256a0|issn=0028-0836|via=}}</ref>
In terms of universality, it is one of the [[List of treaties by number of parties|most successful treaties]] of all time, having been ratified by 197 states (all [[United Nations Climate Change conference|United Nations]] members as well as the [[Holy See]], [[Niue]] and the [[Cook Islands]]) as well as the [[European Union]].<ref name="ratifications">{{cite web|url=http://treaties.un.org/pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=XXVII-2&chapter=27&lang=en|title=Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer|work=[[United Nations Treaty Series]]|accessdate=17 January 2012}}</ref> While not a binding agreement, it acts as a framework for the international efforts to protect the [[ozone layer]]; however, it does not include legally binding reduction goals for the use of [[Chlorofluorocarbon|CFCs]], the main chemical agents causing [[ozone depletion]]. [[File:The Minister of State for Environment, Forest and Climate Change (Independent Charge) (25).jpg|thumb|The Minister of State for Environment, Forest and Climate Change, Shri Prakash Javadekar, addressing at the 21st International Day for the preservation of the ozone layer and the 30th anniversary of the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone layer, in New Delhi on September 16, 2015.]]
=== Provisions === The treaty's provisions include the international sharing of climate and atmospheric research to promote knowledge of the effects on the [[ozone layer]].<ref name="ratifications" /> In addition, the treaty calls for the adoption of international agencies to assess the harmful effects of depleted ozone and the promotion of policies that regulate the production of harmful substances that influence the [[ozone layer]].<ref name="ratifications" /> One of the outcomes of the Vienna Convention was the creation of a panel of governmental atmospheric experts known as the Meeting of Ozone Research Managers, which assesses [[ozone depletion and climate change]] research and produces a report for the [[Conference of the parties|Conference of Parties]] ([[Conference of the parties|COP]]).<ref>{{Cite book|title=Environmental Regime Effectiveness: Confronting Theory with Evidence|last=Wettestad|first=J.|publisher=MIT Press|year=2001|isbn=9780262263726|location=|pages=150}}</ref> Additionally, the [[Conference of the parties|COP]] utilizes the data assessed to suggest new policies aimed at limiting CFC emissions.
Currently, the COP meets every three years and coordinates with the timing of a similar meeting rendered under the [[Montreal Protocol]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/747903390|title=Chemicals, environment, health : a global management perspective|last=Wexler|first=P.|date=2012|publisher=CRC Press|year=|isbn=9781420084696|location=|pages=|oclc=747903390}}</ref> The Ozone Secretariat functions as an administrator of the COP, Montreal Meeting of Parties (MOP), and Open-Ended Working Groups that help facilitate functions under the convention<ref name=":0" />. A Multilateral Fund exists to aid developing nations transition from [[Ozone depletion|ozone-depleting]] chemicals using guidelines under the convention, which is administered by a Multilateral Fund Secretariat.<ref name=":0" /> The Multilateral Fund has aided thousands of projects in nearly 150 countries, preventing the usage of roughly 250,000 tons of [[Ozone depletion|ozone-depleting]] chemicals.<ref name=":0" />

revision.comment: sp.: [[International Labour Organization]], per [[MOS:CONSISTENCY]], proper names use the subject's own spelling (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox Treaty |name = Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties between States and International Organizations or between International Organizations |long_name = |image =File:Convention on the law of treaties (states and international organisations).svg |image_width =350px |caption =States which are signatory or party to the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties between States and International Organizations or between International Organizations {{Col-begin}} {{Col-2}} {{legend|lightgreen|Signatories}} {{legend|green|Parties}} {{Col-end}} |type = |date_drafted = |date_signed = {{dts|21 March 1986}} |location_signed = Vienna |date_sealed = |date_effective = not in force |condition_effective = Ratification by 35 states |date_expiration = |signatories = 39 |parties = 44, among which 32 states |depositor = [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|UN Secretary-General]] |language = |languages = Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian and Spanish |wikisource = }} The '''Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties between States and International Organizations or Between International Organizations ''' ('''VCLTIO''') is an extension of the [[Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties]] which deals with treaties between States. It was developed by the [[International Law Commission]] and opened for signature on 21 March 1986.
Article 85 of the Convention provides that it enters into force after the ratification by 35 states (international organizations may ratify, but their ratification does not count towards the number required for entry into force). As of October 2017, the treaty has been ratified by 32 states and 12 international organizations. As a result, the Convention is not yet in force.<ref>[http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=XXIII-3&chapter=23&lang=en Status of the Convention]</ref>
==Parties to the convention== There are 32 state parties, where the convention is ratified: [[Mexico]], [[Colombia]], [[Argentina]], [[Uruguay]], [[Senegal]], [[Liberia]], [[Gabon]], [[Australia]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Denmark]], [[Sweden]], [[Estonia]], [[Belarus]], [[Moldova]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Cyprus]], [[Greece]], [[Spain]], [[Germany]], [[Kingdom of the Netherlands|Netherlands]],{{refn|group=nb|The convention is ratified on behalf of the whole kingdom, rather than just the constituent country of the [[Netherlands]].}} [[Belgium]], [[Switzerland]], [[Liechtenstein]], [[Italy]], [[Austria]], [[Croatia]], [[Hungary]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Slovakia]], [[Malta]], [[Albania]] and [[State of Palestine|Palestine]].
Additionally, there are 12 international organizations that issued formal confirmations of the convention: [[International Atomic Energy Agency|IAEA]], [[International Civil Aviation Organization|ICAO]], [[International Criminal Police Organization|Interpol]], [[International Labour Organization|ILO]], [[International Maritime Organization|IMO]], [[Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons|OPCW]], [[Preparatory Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty Organization|CTBTO Preparatory Commission]], the [[United Nations|UN]], [[United Nations Industrial Development Organization|UNIDO]], [[Universal Postal Union|UPU]], [[World Health Organization|WHO]], [[World Intellectual Property Organization|WIPO]].
The signatory states that have not ratified are: [[Ivory Coast]], [[Democratic Republic of Congo|DR Congo]], [[United States]], [[Brazil]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[South Korea]], [[Japan]], [[Serbia]], [[Montenegro]], [[Morocco]], [[Egypt]], [[Sudan]], [[Burkina Faso]], [[Benin]], [[Zambia]], and [[Malawi]]. Additionally, there are international organizations that have signed, but not completed their formal confirmation procedures: [[Council of Europe|CoE]], [[Food and Agriculture Organization|FAO]], [[International Telecommunication Union|ITU]], [[United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|UNESCO]] and [[World Meteorological Organization|WMO]].
== See also == * [[Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations]] (1961) * [[Vienna Convention on Consular Relations]] (1963) * [[Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties]] (1969) * [[Vienna Convention (disambiguation)|List of Vienna conventions]] * [[Jus tractatuum]]

New Lenox School District'', 917 F.2d 1004 (7th Cir. 1990)'''{{cite court |litigants=Webster v. New Lenox School District |vol=917 |reporter=F.2d |opinion=1004 |pinpoint= |court=7th Cir. |date=1990 |url=https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F2/917/1004/350874/ |accessdate=2017-10-26 |quote=}} was a court case in Illinois, in which a social studies teacher Ray Webster sued the [[New Lenox School District 122]] in New Lenox, Illinois, which he accused of violating his [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] right to [[free speech]] for stopping him from teaching "[[creation science]]" in class.{{cite web | url = http://ncse.com/taking-action/how-to-testify-at-school-board-meeting | title = How to Testify at School Board Meetings | last = Scott | first = Eugenie C. | authorlink = Eugenie Scott | publisher = [[National Center for Science Education]] | date = March 19, 2001 | accessdate =November 6, 2009}}{{cite web | url =http://ncse.com/taking-action/ten-major-court-cases-evolution-creationism | title = 10 Major Court Cases about Evolution and Creationism | author = Molleen Matsumura |author2=Louise Mead | publisher = [[National Center for Science Education]] | date = July 31, 2007 | accessdate =November 6, 2009}} The court found however that the school district had a right to restrict Webster to teaching the specified curriculum, and that in any case the teaching of "[[creation science]]" was illegal, having been ruled to violate the [[establishment clause]] in the [[United States Supreme Court|U.S. Supreme Court]] decision in [[Edwards v. Aguillard|''Edwards v. Aguillard'', 482 U.S. 578 (1987)]].{{cite web | url = http://www.livescience.com/strangenews/050927_ID_cases.html | title = Anti-evolution Attacks on the Rise | last = Than | first = Ker | publisher = [[Live Science]] | date = September 27, 2005 | accessdate =August 5, 2008}} The case hinged on the school district's "pedagogical interest in establishing the curriculum and legitimate concern with possible establishment clause violations". Webster appealed and the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]] affirmed the District Court's original decision deciding "teaching creation science for any reason was a form of religious advocacy." ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *{{caselaw source | case = ''Webster v. {{For|other uses of "WWCC"|WWCC (disambiguation)}}
The '''Working With Children Check''' ('''WWCC''') is an [[Australia]]n [[background check]] requirement, assessing the [[criminal record]] of those working or volunteering in child-related work. The check is known as the WWCC (or WWC) in most states and territories.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kidsguardian.nsw.gov.au/child-safe-organisations/working-with-children-check|title=Working With Children Check - NSW Office of the Children's Guardian|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.workingwithchildren.vic.gov.au|title=Home|publisher=Department of Justice, Victoria}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://workingwithchildren.wa.gov.au/|title=Home|publisher=Department of Child Protection, Western Australia}}</ref> The equivalent check in [[Queensland]] is known as a "Blue Card."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bluecard.qld.gov.au/|title=Blue Card Services, Department of Justice and Attorney-General|publisher=Queensland Government}}</ref> In the [[Australian Capital Territory|ACT]], the equivalent check is known as the Working with Vulnerable People registration.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.accesscanberra.act.gov.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/1804/~/working-with-vulnerable-people-(wwvp)-registration|title=Home|publisher=ACT Government}}</ref>
In Australia, the Working With Children Check is legislated by each state and territory for the purpose of conducting background checks for people seeking to engage in child-related work. These checks aim to prevent people from working or volunteering with children if records indicate that they may pose an unacceptable level of risk to children. While the check is currently conducted on a state level, an Australian government [[royal commission]] has called for the transition to a nationwide check.<ref name=report>{{cite web|url=https://www.childabuseroyalcommission.gov.au/getattachment/7ecd3db9-0b17-483e-9a0e-8fb247140f3e/Working-with-Children-Checks-Report|title=Working With Children Check Report|publisher=Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/sweeping-changes-needed-to-ensure-child-safety-royal-commission-20150817-gj0lqo.html|title=Home|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> At the same time, some researchers have questioned the effectiveness of a nationwide approach, citing advantages of the particular state scheme developments.<ref name=budi>Budiselik, William, Frances Crawford, and Joan Squelch. "The limits of working with children cards in protecting children." Australian Social Work 62, no. 3 (2009): 339-352.</ref>
==History== In Australia, this form of pre-employment screening for child-related work began in 2000, when the state of [[New South Wales]] introduced its Working With Children Check scheme. Since then, every state and territory has established some form of the scheme. Each of the eight state and territory children check schemes operate independently of each other.<ref name=report/>
In 2016, [[South Australia]] announced it would be switching from a model of criminal background checks to a WWCC model, following a recent royal commission report.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-08-23/sa-working-with-children-checks-to-be-overhauled/7777028?pfmredir=sm|title=SA's Working With Children Checks overhauled after royal commission|date=23 August 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
===Bars=== In New South Wales, since changes to the WWCC system in 2013, about 1,800 people have been barred from working with children in the state.<ref name=tutors/>
===Legislation===
{| class="wikitable" |+ Working With Children Check schemes in Australia ! State ! Name ! Authority ! Commencement ! Legislation |- ! Australian Capital Territory | Working With Vulnerable People (WWVP) check | Background Screening Unit, Access Canberra | 2012 | * ''Working with Vulnerable People (Background Checking) Act 2011'' |- ! New South Wales | Working With Children Check | NSW Office of the Children's Guardian | 2000 | *''Child Protection (Working with Children) Act 2012''<ref>[http://www.legislation.nsw.gov.au/#/view/act/2012/51 ''Child Protection (Working with Children) Act 2012''].</ref> *''Child Protection (Working with Children) Regulation 2013''<ref>[http://www.legislation.nsw.gov.au/#/view/regulation/2013/156 ''Child Protection (Working with Children) Regulation 2013''].</ref> *''Child Protection Legislation Amendment Act 2015''<ref>[http://www.legislation.nsw.gov.au/#/view/act/2015/29 ''Child Protection Legislation Amendment Act 2015''].</ref> |- ! Northern Territory | Working With Children Check / Ochre Card | Screening Assessment for Employment ‚Äì Northern Territory (SAFE NT), Northern Territory Police | 2010 | * ''Care and Protection of Children Act 2007'' |- ! Queensland | Blue Card Check / Working With Children Check | Blue Card Services / Public Safety Business Agency | 2001 | * '' Working with Children (Risk Management and Screening) Act 2000''<ref>[https://www.legislation.qld.gov.au/LEGISLTN/CURRENT/W/WorkwithChildrenRMSA00.pdf '' Working with Children (Risk Management and Screening) Act 2000''].</ref> |- ! South Australia | DCSI screening (changing to WWCC pending legislation commencement) | DCSI Screening Unit (Department for Communities and Social Inclusion) | 2011 | * ''Child Safety (Prohibited Persons) Bill 2016''<ref>[https://yoursay.sa.gov.au/decisions/yoursay-engagements-working-with-children-checks/about ''Child Safety (Prohibited Persons) Bill 2016''].</ref> |- ! Tasmania | Registration to Work with Vulnerable People (RWVP) / Working with Children Registration | Department of Justice | 2014 | * ''Registration to Work with Vulnerable People Act 2013'' * ''Registration to Work with Vulnerable People Regulations 2014'' |- ! Victoria | Working With Children Check | Department of Justice and Regulation, Working with Children Check Unit | 2006 | *''Working with Children Act 2005'' |- ! Western Australia | Working With Children Check | WWC Screening Unit (Department for Child Protection and Family Support) | 2006 | *''Working with Children (Criminal Record Checking) Act 2004'' *''Working with Children (Criminal Record Checking) Regulations 2005'' |}
==Application process== In NSW, the application process involves registering online with the Office of the Children's Guardian, and bringing [[100 point check|100 points of ID]] to a [[Service NSW]] centre. The verification is subsequently emailed to the individual, however, the employer is required to verify the check online as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kidsguardian.nsw.gov.au/FAQ.aspx?SectionID=4#|title=FAQs|publisher=The Children's Guardian}}</ref>
Employers of child-related services need access and update the online WWC system with their current employees to include the Working With Children (WWC) number of each child-related employee. This means that technically if there is an adverse finding in the future, an employer could theoretically be notified, however there is no official requirement to do so, on the contrary, there is concern that lack of coordination between states may allow some adverse issues slip through.<ref>http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-08-17/working-with-children-checks-strengthen-urgently/6703382</ref> According to Working With Children NSW, if the verification result is CLEARED or APPLICATION IN PROGRESS, the worker may commence child-related work. If the verification result is NOT FOUND, EXPIRED, INTERIM BARRED or BARRED, the employer must not employ the worker for child-related work and it is a criminal offence to do so.<ref>http://www.kidsguardian.nsw.gov.au/child-safe-organisations/working-with-children-check/about-the-check/child-related-employers/verifying-a-working-with-children-check-status</ref>
Once a person has a Working With Children Check they can seek employment in child-related work; the Check relates to the individual, not to the specific position of employment. As such, individuals may use the same check for multiple positions or workplaces.<ref>Naylor, Bronwyn. "Criminal records and rehabilitation in Australia." European Journal of Probation 3, no. 1 (2011): 79-96.</ref>
The WWCC expires after a certain time (5 years) and should be renewed before the deadline to avoid employment compliance issues.
===Exemptions=== Certain roles and positions are exempt from the WWCC requirement. For example, in Queensland, [[shopping mall]] [[Santa]]s are exempt, while those hired by schools and other venues are required to undergo the check.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/a/32767674/no-no-no-concern-as-shopping-centre-santas-exempt-from-working-with-children-checks-in-queensland/|title='No, no, no!' Concern as Santas exempt from working with children checks in Queensland|publisher=Yahoo News}}</ref> A parent who volunteers at their child's school may be exempt from the check.<ref>De Plevitz, Loretta. "Systemic racism: The hidden barrier to educational success for Indigenous school students." Australian Journal of Education 51, no. 1 (2007): 54-71.</ref> In other instances, some roles, such as tutors, will require a WWCC in some states but not in others.<ref name=tutors>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/education/parents-are-not-checking-private-tutors-credentials-childrens-guardian-20160707-gq0wf5.html|title=Why parents need to be vigilant about tutors|first=Kelsey|last=Munro|date=9 July 2016|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> Schoolchildren are generally exempt from the check, however, the check is required for Year 12 students who repeated their studies (completing a 13th year), as they turned 18.<ref name=delays>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-04-22/sa-working-with-children-check-backlog/6411646|title=Working with children check backlog forces SA department to double staff, people left unable to work|publisher=ABC News}} 22 Apr 2015.</ref>
===Privacy=== The WWCC is intended to exclude people with inappropriate criminal histories from working with children, but at the same time, it is not a mechanism for accessing individual criminal history information. The WWCC process is actually designed to protect the individual from having to reveal his or her record, as the application is made by the individual, and if rejected is not otherwise publicised.<ref name=budi/>
==Criticism== Some criticism of the WWCC system followed a report that a man being investigated by counter-terrorism authorities, who had previously been involved in a standoff with police at gunpoint in which he threatened them with a sword, continued to be authorised to work with children. Nesha Oneil Hutchinson, President of Australian Childcare Alliance NSW stated that the Working With Children Check system contained serious flaws where unless an individual was convicted of a crime against a child, they may still pass the check. This would allow individuals convicted of crimes against adults to be allowed to work with children. Additionally, the state-based system would possibly allow someone committed of a crime against a child in another state to receive the check as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-08-15/man-charged-with-childcare-fraud-also-arrested-over-sword-attack/7736054|title=Alleged fraudster allowed to work with kids despite sword attack|date=15 August 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2015, final decisions on thousands of applications for checks in [[South Australia]] were delayed due to staffing shortages. In some instances, individuals were unable to work while the applications were still being processed, leading members of the public to call for an interim measure to let people work at least until a new clearance was issued.<ref name=delays/>
